Post-concert debris
causes concern
By JAY S. GOODGOLD
Garbage and debris, such as
beer and wine bottles, left in
Shriver Hall after recent concerts
and movies have caused serious
concern among Plant Planning
personnel, leading to reports that
the facility may be closed to
student groups.
Noting fire and safety hazards,
Chief
George Glaser
Superintendent of Shops, at
Hopkins, warned that if a firc
marshal ever came into Shrivel
during a rock concert he would
have to close it down.
According to the Baltimore
City fire laws, it is illegal to
smoke, drink, or eat in Shriver.
Specifically citing the
Chaplain's Office's "End of the
World Concert," which was held
January 18th, Glaser stated that
Shriver was "a mess," after the
event.
"We found a cigarette butt
ground so deeply into the carpet

streamers were and are still being

concert."

that Shriver would be closed to
in the future to movie showings

"No matter who uses the hall,

minimum of four hours work;
the cost in turn goes back to
those responsible (for the
garbage)."
The Chaplain's Office paid for

"Father Cunningham found beer
cans, bottles, and soda cans on

movie Performance had been

"All we want is for the
students to use it (Shriver), not

want them to use it, but not to
destroy it, or else we could have
a Center Stage."

Jane Fonda addresses capacity Shriver Hall crowd
By MARK DUVOISIN
Jane Fonda, Academy
Award-winning actress and noted
peace activist spoke to a capacity
Shriver Hall audience last night
on the "Political Atrocities Being
Committed in South Vietnam."
"People in South Vietnam are
being tortured in political
prisions which were built with
American dollars," Fonda
declared.
"South Vietnam has the
highest per capita rate of political
prisoners of any country in the
world and we are supporting
these terror tactics," she
continued.

"What we're dealing with is a
situation that is unprecedented.
The United States government is
supplying 92 percent of the
capital required to sustain the
South Vietnamese government. It
is time for the American people
to become aware of this fact and
decide if we want our priorities
in that order," she added.
Scandal
"What's going on in South
Vietnam isn't common news to
enough people, but it will be
soon. Remember Mylai — when it
first broke it wasn't an issue. But
then a few industrious journalists
did some research and it became

a scandal of major proportion,"
she said.
Although Fonda addressed
herself primarily to American
involvement in Indochina, she
dedicated a portion of the
presentation to activism in the
1960's.
"Before I got up here to speak,
the same thing happened that
always happens whenever I speak
on a college campus," said
Fonda. "Your organizers told me
that: 'this campus is really
conservative, nothing ever
happens here."
"I can be sympathetic because
I was apathetic for 31 years. I

just recently became an activist. I
was in school during the
McCarthy hearings, during that
whole anti-communist era," she
said. "We were told certain things
— other things were withheld
from uS," she added.
. "The major effect of the
McCarthy era was that it cut
people off. That's why we grew
up cynical and apathetic...and if
you were a woman it was worse,"
she added.
Fonda devoted a large part of
the speech to a commentary on
women's rights. "To grow up as a

possibility of energy shutdown due to lack of fuel
The Homewood Campus uses natural gas as fuel, under a contract with the Gas and Electric Company which
permits service to be interrupted on six hours' notice. Such interruption usually occurs in cold weather, when demand for natural gas is high.
When natural gas is not available, fuel oil is used. Present storage of 28,000 gallons is sufficient for two days of
operation in cold weather. Oil deliveries twice a day are required to keep the physical plant in continuous operation.
Despite the shortage of oil, we have thus far been able to arrange deliveries as necessary.
There is no expectation of an immediate emergency. However, if fuel becomes unavailable in sufficient supply to
maintain operations, an emergency shutdown will be called.
In an Emergency Shutdown, the only areas which will receive. heat are the dormitories, the animal quarters in
Ames and the Greenhouse, and the apartment houses (which haVe separate heating systems). A limited number of
administrative personnel will be working in Garland Hall, which is heated by electricity and is therefore not dependent on either natural gas or oil. All other buildings, including the Library, will be closed — and heat will be provided only in sufficient amount to prevent freeze-up.
If an Emergency Shutdown should become necessary, word will be sent from the Office of the Vice President for
the Homewood Divisions by messenger to each administrative office. The notice will give the time and date of the
Shutdown.
Classes will be cancelled during an Emergency Shutdown. Notification of cancellation of evening classes will be
provided to radio stations for broadcast during the interval 4:00 to 6:00 p.m. Notice of cancellation of daytime
classes will be provided to radio stations for announcement from 6:00 to 9:00 a.m. Notice of the ending of the
Emergency will be broadcast during the same two intervals.
You are reminded that there is no expectation that an Emergency Shutdown will be necessary in the immediate
future. This notice is for your information only.

By MICHAEL MANES
Last Friday evening, poet
Anne Sexton completely
enchanted an attentive audience
in the Garrett Room with both
her poetry and her philosophy,
marking the first event of "Next
Step: A Festival of Women."
Sexton, a native of
Massachusetts, has won many
major awards, including the
Pulitzer prize, a membership in
the American Academy of Arts
and Sciences, as well as a
professorship at Tufts University.
At the start of the lecture
Sexton not only forced the
audience to listen but to think.
"What happens if an artist
fails?" asked Sexton.
"An artist must be allowed to
fail, even in this society. If an
artist doesn't dare to fail, but
onl attempts to stay at a level of
popular success, then this is
nothing. And the artist is
nothing," she asserted.
Beginning her readings with
selections from het first book,
Sexton also read from The
Furies, Love Poems, and Live or
Die.

Madness," Sexton's poems are
marked with an original and fresh
style of metaphors. Her poetry is

Chaplain slates new programs

To impeach, or not to impeach (some ?!)
Three members of the Political
Science Department addressed
the topic of Watergate and the
question of Presidential
Impeachment at the Sunday
Experience in Shriver Hall
Sunday morning.
Dr. J. Woodford Howard,
Chairman of the Political Science
Department, and department
colleagues Dr. Matthew Crenson,
and Dr. Francis Rourke,
presented personal, often
candid , views of the Watergate
situation - focusing primarily on
the stability of the Presidency
under present and future
circumstances.
Howard opened the session
with an outline of impeachment
and the conditions needed for its
implementation.
Howard contended first that
the executive leader would have
to suffer a massive loss of public
confidence in him. Second, this
loss of public confidence would
have to be of such proportion to
force political leaders of the

Alan Sapakie

President's party to act for his
removal.
Third, Howard cited the
question of the "high crimes or
misdeamenors" on the part of
the executive officer as the final
factor to be considered before
undertaking impeachment
proceedings.
As for the chance of successful
impeachment if proceedings were
to begin today, Howard
presented his personal view that
President Nixon has abused his
executive power and has
substantially moved to obstruct
justice to an extent that would
presently warrant impeachment
on legal grounds.
Iloward asserted however that,
because of the "fuzziness" of the
Constitutional definition of
impeachment, the House of
Representatives would be
presently unable to act
affirmatively on this matter.
"I would doubt that there are
sufficient votes to vote on this
account in the House." Howard

stated.
"In the Senate, the case is
probably the same," he added.
Howard expressed concern
over the reluctance on the part of
legislators to act on the question.
"I think that there is a feeling
that the impeachment process is
tainted and not a real function of
the constitution," he continued.
"If this is true, there is a fear
of this process atrophying."
Thirdly, Howard warned against
adopting a purists' attitude that
"We've got to go through an
impeachment process" as a
means of warding off this
atrophy.
Crenson followed Howard's
remaks with a casual editorial.
Crenson maintained that
despite a sufficient amount of
legal evidence to bring about
impeachment, the "political
determination" in both legislative
bodies to enact the proceedings i5
lacking.
"And I don't think that new
evidence is going to develop this

political determination," Crenson
commented.
Crenson went on to cite
Nixon's role as a defensive one,
pointing out that most attention
will be focused on Nixon's
actions today, not his past
wrongdoings, which have put him
on the defensive although only
to he is still in the White House.
"The unpredictability of the
Watergate Affair has worked
successfully against the President
thus far. So, in light of this. the
President is going to be in trouble
for a long time," Crenson assured
his audience.
Rourke concluded the trilogy
with a look at the state of the
Presidency.
"I've always been ready to
impeach Richard Nixon, even
when he wasn't in office,"
Rourke stated.
The Political Science
department's Presidential
specialist then went on to
examine how the position of the
presidency had been tainted.

Barnstormers production of Hedda Gabler

forgotten but not lost
Most people around here have probably forgotten by
now that the hottest issue of last semester was the matter of
freshman grading, and it now appears that the entire
controversy was over very little.
For the results of a nationwide poll of graduate and
professional schools, conducted by a subcommittee of the
Committee on Undergraduate Studies, indicate no clear trend
among such schools in their opinions on the issue. Thus,
contrary to the dark predictions of last fall that noone who
withheld his first semester grades would ever get into medical
school seem somewhat extreme.
Unfortunately, when the entire grading matter came up
last fall, decisions were made and positions were stated, but
no one had any idea what the situation really was. Neither
the Dean's office nor students involved in the controversy
made any systematic effort to find out how much the
absence of a student's first semester grades would actually
affect his chances of getting into a graduate school.
One member of the subcommittee said of the study
results, "The responses could be read either way," and
another member stated, "They were vague and indecisive." If
anyone had bothered to ask graduate schools last semester,
all the bitterness and recrimination that took place could
have been avoided. Next time a major issue hits the campus,
we hope that the people involved, both administrators and
students, will make an effort to find out what the facts of the
matter are, instead of becoming arouseds and making
decisions without having any idea what is really going on.

By CHARLES PINNING
As their first production of
1974, the Barnstormers have
chosen to stage the classic Ibsen
play Hedda Gabler. Technically,

daughter of the late General
Gabler. It is implicit in the story
that, as Hedda grew up, her father

supplying her with all of the
material needs she desired

to know of pain, risk and

would relate to her. Because she

To the Editor:
The letter by Feinberg shows
the typical leftist ivory-tower
"Ubermensch" mentality at work
again: don't bother with such
bourgeois things as logic and
refuting arguments, just throw the
usual propaganda pharases and
hope everybody's too snowed to
notice. When he gets done with his
could be's and could also's and
might wonderings and might
questionings, we get down to the
nitty-gritty, which is the simplistic
equation of fascism with
government by the military, a
dubious assumption at best. For
leftists such as Feinberg, the
double standard runs rampant on a
field of hypocrisy: a dictatorship
run by the local military is bad, a
dictatorship manipulated by

went to Chile even more

absolutely inconceivable to me
therefore, that the man is a)lying,
b) a mental incompetent, c) an

months, or d) having a rifle
pointed at his head as he writes.
Therefore, the only conclusion one
can make - an incredible one, I
admit! - is that Feinberg, never
having been to Chile, just doesn't
know the score. Unless, of course

from Hanoi Jane and I've just
blown his cover. Sorry about that,
Joel.
If this is the best example of
New-Old Left reasoning, what's a
youthful idealist like me got left to
believe in?
Dick Oles

Because, despite his talents as a

looked good for Hedda to have
married Lovborg.
The play beings. Hedda and
Tesman have just returned to their
new villa after a honeymoon of
nearly six months the bulk of
which Tesman spent doing research
in various European libraries and
Hedda spent sitting alone in hotel
rooms or acquiring new dresses.

she doesn't want a scandal, she had
better accept the triangle as a
reality: everyday blackmail. This
painful reality (like all others) she
cannot face, so she shoots herself.
This is lbsen's Play.
From the top: Lydia Firestone
is a good actress with considerable
stage presense. She effectively
creates a cold and aloof Hedda.
But then something else happens
for which the director must accept
much of the responsibility: We lose
the sense of Hedda's boredom and
purposelessness and a new Hedda,
an evil Hedda is created. She no
longer is a victim of her
socialization as Ibsen had intended,
but becomes a self-generating evil
spirit.
The Hedda created in this
production would have thrived
within the triangular relationship
and not shot herself. This Hedda
seemed to be gaining inner strength
instead of losing it at the end. In
fact, I see no reason why this
Hedda would not have married
Lovborg in the first place.
Miss Firestone is saying the
words that Ibsen wrote but her
persona is saying something else. If
only the director could let us see
the Consumate agony of anomie
on her face as she looks out the
windows into the blue instead .
having her turn her full back to us
and have her appear as a plotting
schemer. She also throws away
several important lines, most
notably in the last scene where in a
final effort she approaches Tesman
and asks, "Is there nothing I can
do to make myself useful?" and he
dismisses her by saying,"NO, not a
thing." This is the story of Hedda's
life. As she was probably shunted
off by her father so she is now by
her husband.
This production allows us to feel
no sympathy for Hedda. It simply
creates a somewhat sinister bitch
sho shoots herself and we're glad
that she does. In the end Hedda
asks that question she must have
asked as a little girl and again is
rejected.
So she goes into the back room
and bangs on the piano for
attention and is reproached. Poor
little child/Hedda is asking to be
noticed to be loved to be given a
chance, a chance she never had.

Becoming a physician is a tremendous
satisfaction.
Let us give you the job satisfaction
that should go with it.
Whether you're still in medical school with the
rigors of three to five years of graduate medical education still to be faced, or are already a practicing
physician, it's our opinion that the Air Force can
offer both professional and personal satisfaction
hard to duplicate in civilian life.
An overstatement? Not if you consider the
specifics.
Take the problem of graduate medical education. It's a period of your life the Air Force can make
considerably easier with comfortable salary and living conditions.
Creature comforts aside, the Air Force offers
professional advantages. Besides receiving training
in your own specialty, you'd be in contact with
physicians in all of the medical specialties. You'll
function in an environment which is intellectually
stimulating and professionally challenging.
Not all physicians pursue post residency fellowships. But if you are interested, the Air Force conducts them both in-house and at civilian institutions.
The physician already in practice can look forward to other things. If you want training in the
practice of the medicine of the future, you'll find it
in the Air Force. For example, there's emphasis on
group medicine and preventive medicine, and the
growing specialty of "family physician." Whatever
your interest, there are few specialties which are not
being practiced in today's Air Force.
The physician starting his practice in civilian
life has to take into account the cost of setting up an
office. The physician commencing his -practice in

the Air Force does not. He finds his office established
for him. Supplies and equipment readily available.
He has many options available to him when treating
patients. For example,he can consult with Air Force
specialists. He also has referral to other Air Force
facilities via aeromedical evacuation. Last, but not
least, are the satisfactions that come with having
the opportunity for regular follow-ups, and a missed
appointment rate that is practically
Whether you are already a physician, or soon to
become one, you might find it extremely interesting
to rind out what the Air Force has to offer. We think
it could be a real eye-opener. If you'll mail in the coupon, we'd be happy to send you detailed information.

Matmen lose to American, Towson State
By ROBERT ROSENWASSER
The Blue Jay wrestling squad
ran its record to 5 wins and 4
losses as they suffered two
defeats at the hands of American
University on Wednesday and
Towson State College on
Saturday.
American and Towson State
were two of the toughest
opponents Hopkins will face this
year. The competition was stiff
and the wrestling quality high.
Hopkins dropped its match to
American 26-18 and lost to
Towson by the Score of 22-12.
The total offense generated for
Hopkins in the American match
were three pins turned in by
Steve Lazzaro at 118 pounds
Neil Hazzard at 190 pounds, and
Gary Murza at heavyweight.
Despite the 22-12 score in the
Towson State match, the
difference in the mptch was a
pair of one point victory
decisions posted by Towson
State at 150 pounds and 190
pounds.
Each match started strong for
Hopkins as freshman Steve
Lazzaro continued to dump his

opponents by big margins. He ran
his dual meet record to 7-1 when
he took a 10-2 decison from
Towson's Dave Wittenburg.
Lazzaro was stalemated on his
feet in the first period, but an
escape and take down in the
second period gave him a 3-0
edge going into the final period.
Lazzaro then turned Wittenburg
twice with the head and ribs
cradle en route to victory.
The Dynamic Duo found the
going rough during the past week
as both Ron Pucillo and Mike
Privitera dropped decisions
against their American and
Towson State opponents. Pucillo
faced Ed Garono of Towson
State. Garono was last year's
Mason-Dixon champion for the
Tigers.
Hopkins had one shut out in
the Towson State match. It was
Clark Kingery at 142 pounds
blanking Larry Lidard by the
score of 5-0 Kingery was good
on his feet but Lidard refused to
give Kingery the takedown.
Kingery rode out Lidard superbly
in the second period. Going into
the third period, the match was

scoreless But Clark turned things
around as he reversed Lidard
early in the third period. Kingery
then turned Lidard to his back
for a near fall and was awarded
one point for riding time, giving
him a well-deserved 5-0 shutout.
Space Cowboy
Had Hopkins turned the 2
single point losses into victories,
the final score Saturday would
have been 18-16 in favor of the
Blue Jays.

Again a little overanxious play
spelled defeat when DeLong
passed inside with 22 seconds
left. The ubiquitious Newman
reached in to make the steal,
then pumped the ball home from
twenty feet with three seconds
showing to ice the contest.
The game was a bitter loss for

avid followers of the team, takes

Center when the Jays take on the

contest to decide first place in

Jane Fonda, Academy
Award-winning actress and noted
peace activist spoke to a capacity
Shriver Hall audience last night
on the "Political Atrocities Being
Committed in South Vietnam."
"People in South Vietnam are
being tortured in political
prisions which were built with
American dollars," Fonda
declared.
"South Vietnam has the
highest per capita rate of political
prisoners of any country in the
world and we are supporting
these terror tactics," she
continued.

"What we're dealing with is a
situation that is unprecedented.
The United States government is
supplying 92 percent of the
capital required to sustain the
South Vietnamese government. It
is time for the American people
to become aware of this fact and
decide if we want our priorities
in that order," she added.
Scandal
"What's going on in South
Vietnam isn't common news to
enough people, but it will be
soon. Remember Mylai — when it
first broke it wasn't an issue. But
then a few industrious journalists
did some research and it became

a scandal of major proportion,"
she said.
Although Fonda addressed
herself primarily to American
involvement in Indochina, she
dedicated a portion of the
presentation to activism in the
1960's.
"Before I got up here to speak,
the same thing happened that
always happens whenever I speak
on a college campus," said
Fonda. "Your organizers told me
that: 'this campus is really
conservative, nothing ever
happens here."

I was apathetic for 31 years. I

was in school during the

said. "We were told certain things

from uS," she added.

possibility of energy shutdown due to lack of fuel
The Homewood Campus uses natural gas as fuel, under a contract with the Gas and Electric Company which
permits service to be interrupted on six hours' notice. Such interruption usually occurs in cold weather, when demand for natural gas is high.
When natural gas is not available, fuel oil is used. Present storage of 28,000 gallons is sufficient for two days of
operation in cold weather. Oil deliveries twice a day are required to keep the physical plant in continuous operation.
Despite the shortage of oil, we have thus far been able to arrange deliveries as necessary.
There is no expectation of an immediate emergency. However, if fuel becomes unavailable in sufficient supply to
maintain operations, an emergency shutdown will be called.
In an Emergency Shutdown, the only areas which will receive. heat are the dormitories, the animal quarters in
Ames and the Greenhouse, and the apartment houses (which haVe separate heating systems). A limited number of
administrative personnel will be working in Garland Hall, which is heated by electricity and is therefore not dependent on either natural gas or oil. All other buildings, including the Library, will be closed — and heat will be provided only in sufficient amount to prevent freeze-up.
If an Emergency Shutdown should become necessary, word will be sent from the Office of the Vice President for
the Homewood Divisions by messenger to each administrative office. The notice will give the time and date of the
Shutdown.
Classes will be cancelled during an Emergency Shutdown. Notification of cancellation of evening classes will be
provided to radio stations for broadcast during the interval 4:00 to 6:00 p.m. Notice of cancellation of daytime
classes will be provided to radio stations for announcement from 6:00 to 9:00 a.m. Notice of the ending of the
Emergency will be broadcast during the same two intervals.
You are reminded that there is no expectation that an Emergency Shutdown will be necessary in the immediate
future. This notice is for your information only.

To impeach, or not to impeach (some ?!)
Three members of the Political
Science Department addressed
the topic of Watergate and the
question of Presidential
Impeachment at the Sunday
Experience in Shriver Hall
Sunday morning.
Dr. J. Woodford Howard,
Chairman of the Political Science
Department, and department
colleagues Dr. Matthew Crenson,
and Dr. Francis Rourke,
presented personal, often
candid , views of the Watergate
situation - focusing primarily on
the stability of the Presidency
under present and future
circumstances.
Howard opened the session
with an outline of impeachment
and the conditions needed for its
implementation.
Howard contended first that
the executive leader would have
to suffer a massive loss of public
confidence in him. Second, this
loss of public confidence would
have to be of such proportion to
force political leaders of the

Alan Sapakie

President's party to act for his
removal.
Third, Howard cited the
question of the "high crimes or
misdeamenors" on the part of
the executive officer as the final
factor to be considered before
undertaking impeachment
proceedings.
As for the chance of successful
impeachment if proceedings were
to begin today, Howard
presented his personal view that
President Nixon has abused his
executive power and has
substantially moved to obstruct
justice to an extent that would
presently warrant impeachment
on legal grounds.
Iloward asserted however that,
because of the "fuzziness" of the
Constitutional definition of
impeachment, the House of
Representatives would be
presently unable to act
affirmatively on this matter.
"I would doubt that there are
sufficient votes to vote on this
account in the House." Howard

stated.
"In the Senate, the case is
probably the same," he added.
Howard expressed concern
over the reluctance on the part of
legislators to act on the question.
"I think that there is a feeling
that the impeachment process is
tainted and not a real function of
the constitution," he continued.
"If this is true, there is a fear
of this process atrophying."
Thirdly, Howard warned against
adopting a purists' attitude that
"We've got to go through an
impeachment process" as a
means of warding off this
atrophy.
Crenson followed Howard's
remaks with a casual editorial.
Crenson maintained that
despite a sufficient amount of
legal evidence to bring about
impeachment, the "political
determination" in both legislative
bodies to enact the proceedings i5
lacking.
"And I don't think that new
evidence is going to develop this

political determination," Crenson
commented.
Crenson went on to cite
Nixon's role as a defensive one,
pointing out that most attention
will be focused on Nixon's
actions today, not his past
wrongdoings, which have put him
on the defensive although only
to he is still in the White House.
"The unpredictability of the
Watergate Affair has worked
successfully against the President
thus far. So, in light of this. the
President is going to be in trouble
for a long time," Crenson assured
his audience.
Rourke concluded the trilogy
with a look at the state of the
Presidency.
"I've always been ready to
impeach Richard Nixon, even
when he wasn't in office,"
Rourke stated.
The Political Science
department's Presidential
specialist then went on to
examine how the position of the
presidency had been tainted.

Case stated the Chaplain's

these sessions once a week and
possible twice a week," said Case.

Barnstormers production of Hedda Gabler

forgotten but not lost
Most people around here have probably forgotten by
now that the hottest issue of last semester was the matter of
freshman grading, and it now appears that the entire
controversy was over very little.
For the results of a nationwide poll of graduate and
professional schools, conducted by a subcommittee of the
Committee on Undergraduate Studies, indicate no clear trend
among such schools in their opinions on the issue. Thus,
contrary to the dark predictions of last fall that noone who
withheld his first semester grades would ever get into medical
school seem somewhat extreme.
Unfortunately, when the entire grading matter came up
last fall, decisions were made and positions were stated, but
no one had any idea what the situation really was. Neither
the Dean's office nor students involved in the controversy
made any systematic effort to find out how much the
absence of a student's first semester grades would actually
affect his chances of getting into a graduate school.
One member of the subcommittee said of the study
results, "The responses could be read either way," and
another member stated, "They were vague and indecisive." If
anyone had bothered to ask graduate schools last semester,
all the bitterness and recrimination that took place could
have been avoided. Next time a major issue hits the campus,
we hope that the people involved, both administrators and
students, will make an effort to find out what the facts of the
matter are, instead of becoming arouseds and making
decisions without having any idea what is really going on.

daughter of the late General
Gabler. It is implicit in the story
that, as Hedda grew up, her father
paved a smooth road for her,
removing all obstacles and
supplying her with all of the
material needs she desired
Perhaps he had led an exciting
life, rich with dangerous and
exciting adventures, but we can be
assured that all Hedda was allowed
to know of pain, risk and
adventure were the stories he
would relate to her. Because she
was a female and his daughter, she
was sheltered from all

To the Editor:
The letter by Feinberg shows
the typical leftist ivory-tower
"Ubermensch" mentality at work
again: don't bother with such
bourgeois things as logic and
refuting arguments, just throw the
usual propaganda pharases and
hope everybody's too snowed to
notice. When he gets done with his
could be's and could also's and
might wonderings and might
questionings, we get down to the
nitty-gritty, which is the simplistic
equation of fascism with
government by the military, a
dubious assumption at best. For
leftists such as Feinberg, the
double standard runs rampant on a
field of hypocrisy: a dictatorship
run by the local military is bad, a
dictatorship manipulated by

went to Chile even more
entrenched in it than ever. It is
absolutely inconceivable to me
therefore, that the man is a)lying,
b) a mental incompetent, c) an
ideological turncoat within two
months, or d) having a rifle
pointed at his head as he writes.
Therefore, the only conclusion one
can make - an incredible one, I
admit! - is that Feinberg, never
having been to Chile, just doesn't
know the score. Unless, of course
he's been there under secret orders
from Hanoi Jane and I've just
blown his cover. Sorry about that,
Joel.
If this is the best example of
New-Old Left reasoning, what's a
youthful idealist like me got left to
believe in?
Dick Oles

Hedda Gabler as child/corpse.

As the play progresses Eilert
Lovborg surfaces. Prior to Hedda's
marriage to Tesman, Lovborg was

Because, despite his talents as a
writer, he has a reputation as a
debaucher. It would not have

married Lovborg.
The play beings. Hedda and
Tesman have just returned to their
new villa after a honeymoon of
nearly six months the bulk of
which Tesman spent doing research
in various European libraries and
Hedda spent sitting alone in hotel
rooms or acquiring new dresses.

Becoming a physician is a tremendous
satisfaction.
Let us give you the job satisfaction
that should go with it.
Whether you're still in medical school with the
rigors of three to five years of graduate medical education still to be faced, or are already a practicing
physician, it's our opinion that the Air Force can
offer both professional and personal satisfaction
hard to duplicate in civilian life.
An overstatement? Not if you consider the
specifics.
Take the problem of graduate medical education. It's a period of your life the Air Force can make
considerably easier with comfortable salary and living conditions.
Creature comforts aside, the Air Force offers
professional advantages. Besides receiving training
in your own specialty, you'd be in contact with
physicians in all of the medical specialties. You'll
function in an environment which is intellectually
stimulating and professionally challenging.
Not all physicians pursue post residency fellowships. But if you are interested, the Air Force conducts them both in-house and at civilian institutions.
The physician already in practice can look forward to other things. If you want training in the
practice of the medicine of the future, you'll find it
in the Air Force. For example, there's emphasis on
group medicine and preventive medicine, and the
growing specialty of "family physician." Whatever
your interest, there are few specialties which are not
being practiced in today's Air Force.
The physician starting his practice in civilian
life has to take into account the cost of setting up an
office. The physician commencing his -practice in

the Air Force does not. He finds his office established
for him. Supplies and equipment readily available.
He has many options available to him when treating
patients. For example,he can consult with Air Force
specialists. He also has referral to other Air Force
facilities via aeromedical evacuation. Last, but not
least, are the satisfactions that come with having
the opportunity for regular follow-ups, and a missed
appointment rate that is practically
Whether you are already a physician, or soon to
become one, you might find it extremely interesting
to rind out what the Air Force has to offer. We think
it could be a real eye-opener. If you'll mail in the coupon, we'd be happy to send you detailed information.

Hoopsters fall to Drexel, 57-55, despite excellent play
The Blue Jay basketball team
saw their five-game win streak
come to an end last Saturday at
Drexel, falling to the Dragons
57-55. The contest resulted in a
moral victory for the Jays, who
played excellent ball against a
heavily favored foe, but this fact
provided little solace for a squad
attempting to tie the school
mark for consecutive wins.
Hopkins came out firing in the
first half, running a bit more than
their patterned offense usually
allows. Shooting at a better than
50% clip, the Jays seemed to
surprise even themselves by
keeping up with their hosts.
Gradually gaining confidence, the

Jays handcuffed Drexel's leading
scorers while Bobby Freedman
and Greg DeLong bombed away
from the fringes. The Dragons
missed 12 consecutive shots at
one point- while Freedman rifled
home five in a row, resulting in a
Blue Jay lead of 32-22. A pair of
cold spells by the Jays were
negated in the closing minutes by
the Birds' excellent defense and
Hopkins owned a 34-26 edge at
halftime.
Drexel had nowhere to go but
up in the second half, realizing
their College Division opponent
was not to be taken lightly. It fell
upon the shoulders of 6-3 guard
Greg Newman to make things

NEws-krret

happen for the Dragons. The
senior co-captain had destroyed
the Blue Jays at Homewood last
season with an 18 point, 10
rebound outburst, but had been
less a factor in the rematch to
this point. Newman found his
outside shot once again in the
opening minutes of the second
stanza, however and the Dragons
were back in the game.
The Jays maintained their
10-point lead throughout
Newman's opening barrage with
some sharpshooting on the part
of Greg DeLong, but Newman,
with the help of a little
protection from .the men in
striped shirts, found additional

Swimmers defeat LaSalle, 58-55
By STEVEN LEVIN
The LaSalle Explorers were
the victims when the Hopkins
Swimmers travelled to
Philadelphia and came away with
a 58-55 victory Saturday.
However, it seemed that the Jays
were the real "Explorers" since it
/
2 hours to
took the team bus 41
venture from Homewood to
Philadelphia.
Scheduled to start at 3:00, the
meet finally got underway at
4:00 and the Comforteers, tired
from the long bus ride, took to
the water in what was to be one
of the closest meets in • Coach
Comfort's 5 years at Hopkins.
The Jays started the meet off
with a splash, as their best relay
team, Horning, Stoever, Milne
and Patzschke, won the 400 yd.

medley relay in 3:40.116. But
the order of finish in the next
event, the 1000 yd. freestyle, set
the tone for the rest of the meet.
Eric Engelmann won it in
10:24.61 but LaSalle took 2nd
and 3rd place. This pattern
continued throughout the meet
as Stoever's victories in the 200
yd. individual medlye and 200
yd. breaststroke, Patzschke's win
in the 100 yd. freestyle,
Horning's triumph in the 200 yd.
backstroke and Milne's rout in
the 500 yd. freestyle; all found
Hopkins taking 1st while losing
2nd and 3rd.
Sweet Revenge
Though there were no record
breaking performances, the Jays
were led by 3 double winners:
Milne, Stoever and Patzschke.

Also Fred Rudolph's
come-from -behind 2nd place
finish in the 200 yd. butterfly
and Marc Tohir's 2nd in the 3
meter divingswere the highlights
of the competition.
There was almost a first in so
far as Hopkins swimming goes.
But, for lack of a bathing suit,
Blue Jay fresh(man?) mermaid,
Roxanne Miller, missed her first
try in varsity competition.(None
of the guys even offered to lend
her a suit; what kind of team
spirit is that??) Well, maybe next
meet. The next meet for the
Comforteers is Saturday,
February 9, at home against
another NCAA University
division opponent: Westchester
State (Pa.). Starting time is 2:30
in Homewood Pool.

Matmen lose to American, Towson State
By ROBERT ROSENWASSER
The Blue Jay wrestling squad
ran its record to 5 wins and 4
losses as they suffered two
defeats at the hands of American
University on Wednesday and
Towson State College on
Saturday.
American and Towson State
were two of the toughest
opponents Hopkins will face this
year. The competition was stiff
and the wrestling quality high.
Hopkins dropped its match to
American 26-18 and lost to
Towson by the Score of 22-12.
The total offense generated for
Hopkins in the American match
were three pins turned in by
Steve Lazzaro at 118 pounds
Neil Hazzard at 190 pounds, and
Gary Murza at heavyweight.
Despite the 22-12 score in the
Towson State match, the
difference in the mptch was a
pair of one point victory
decisions posted by Towson
State at 150 pounds and 190
pounds.
Each match started strong for
Hopkins as freshman Steve
Lazzaro continued to dump his

opponents by big margins. He ran
his dual meet record to 7-1 when
he took a 10-2 decison from
Towson's Dave Wittenburg.
Lazzaro was stalemated on his
feet in the first period, but an
escape and take down in the
second period gave him a 3-0
edge going into the final period.
Lazzaro then turned Wittenburg
twice with the head and ribs
cradle en route to victory.
The Dynamic Duo found the
going rough during the past week
as both Ron Pucillo and Mike
Privitera dropped decisions
against their American and
Towson State opponents. Pucillo
faced Ed Garono of Towson
State. Garono was last year's
Mason-Dixon champion for the
Tigers.
Hopkins had one shut out in
the Towson State match. It was
Clark Kingery at 142 pounds
blanking Larry Lidard by the
score of 5-0 Kingery was good
on his feet but Lidard refused to
give Kingery the takedown.
Kingery rode out Lidard superbly
in the second period. Going into
the third period, the match was

scoreless But Clark turned things
around as he reversed Lidard
early in the third period. Kingery
then turned Lidard to his back
for a near fall and was awarded
one point for riding time, giving
him a well-deserved 5-0 shutout.
Space Cowboy
Had Hopkins turned the 2
single point losses into victories,
the final score Saturday would
have been 18-16 in favor of the
Blue Jays.

Again a little overanxious play
spelled defeat when DeLong
passed inside with 22 seconds
left. The ubiquitious Newman
reached in to make the steal,
then pumped the ball home from
twenty feet with three seconds
showing to ice the contest.
The game was a bitter loss for
Coach Gary Rupert. who felt his
team played a "near-flawless
game." The Jays outshot the
Dragons from the floor by eight
points, yet managed 5 of 6 from
the line to Drexel's 15 of 15.
Although Hopkins lost the battle
of the boards 34-32 they held
their own against a much more
physical squad.
The loss drops Hopkins to a
10-6 record, but does not affect
their 6-1 conference mark. The
Jays take to the road again
tomorrow to face the
Midshipmen of Navy in a 4 p.m.
contest. Directions to the
Academy can be obtained at the
Athletic Center. Hopkins returns
home Thursday night, resuming
MAC league play against Ursinus
at 8:30 p.m. "The Game," for all
avid followers of the team, takes
place Saturday at the Athletic
Center when the Jays take on the
Dickinson Red Devils in the
contest to decide first place in
the conference.

Holdridge would make a nice pile

concluding a successful week for
the heavyweight despite the Blue

The Blue Jay grapplers host
